close_symbols: struct OS_FdSet (full definition, specifically the object_ids member: element type and array length)
OS_SUCCESS (macro / enum value used as success return)
OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM (macro/enum value used as argument to ObjectIdToArrayIndex)
explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required for bounds-safety analysis:

- struct OS_FdSet (full definition, specifically the object_ids member: element type and array length): The function indexes Set->object_ids using (local_id >> 3). To determine whether this access can go out of bounds we must know the element type (e.g., uint8_t) and the array length (number of elements) so we can compare the computed index (local_id >> 3) against the array bounds.

- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex (function prototype and implementation / behavior): This routine produces local_id from objid and returns success/failure. To prove the bit-indexing is safe we must know the exact contract: the possible range of local_id values it returns on OS_SUCCESS (minimum and maximum), and whether it can return values that map outside the object_ids array. The implementation also shows whether any additional normalization/clamping occurs.

- osal_index_t (typedef): The integer type and width/signedness of local_id affects arithmetic, shifting, and comparisons. Knowing the typedef ensures correct interpretation of shifts and index computation (and whether sign-extension or overflow is possible).

- osal_id_t (typedef): Knowing the type of objid can be important if ObjectIdToArrayIndex behavior depends on the size/format of objid (e.g., if objid encodes type/serial fields) and to ensure no implicit narrowing/undefined behavior occurs before conversion.

- OS_SUCCESS (macro / enum value used as success return): Needed to interpret ObjectIdToArrayIndex return and confirm the code path that uses local_id only executes when the function returned success; ensures we apply bounds reasoning only to values returned under the OS_SUCCESS contract.

- BUGCHECK (macro definition/behavior): The function calls BUGCHECK(Set != NULL, false). We need to know whether BUGCHECK aborts, returns, or otherwise affects control flow or validation semantics; this influences whether the following code must defend against Set == NULL or whether it can assume a valid pointer.

- OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM (macro/enum value used as argument to ObjectIdToArrayIndex): The object type passed to ObjectIdToArrayIndex may change the valid range of local_id. To determine bounds we must know which object-type mapping is used so we can relate local_id limits to the OS_FdSet->object_ids size.

Together these symbols allow a precise check that (local_id >> 3) is strictly less than the number of elements in Set->object_ids and that the bit shift (local_id & 0x7) indexes a valid bit within an element — thereby confirming whether any out-of-bounds memory access (the kind of violation the <string.h> rule aims to prevent for analogous buffer operations) can occur. Note: the target function does not call any <string.h> functions; the concern here is bounds safety of the bit-array access, so the above symbols are required to prove safety.
